content.text: A ‘case-control study’ is where a group of people are invited to take part based on particular characteristic(s) or ‘exposure’ to something (e.g., child abuse or a given health condition) and are directly compared on given measures of interest to those without the condition or exposure.

attrs.alt:
A black rectangle with a black background

content.text: The below quality guide is based on the following established quality assessment checklist:
Did the study try to answer a clear and focused question or issue?

content.text: Did the authors publicly share a detailed plan or ‘protocol’ of how they would go about doing the study before they completed it? If they did, did they stick closely to the final study publication?
If so, please add relevant weblink for the trial protocol here:

content.text: Have the authors tried to take into account things that might give the false impression that there are important differences between the case and control groups (i.e., ‘potential confounding factors’) in the design of the study itself and/or in when ‘crunching their data’?
